column1: Table 4-23:  Average Fuel Efficiency of U.S. Light Duty Vehicles
Average U.S. light duty vehicle fuel efficiency (mpg) (calendar year)
Light duty vehicle, short wheel basea,b
Light duty vehicle, long wheel basea
New vehicle fuel efficiency (mpg)c (model year)
Light-duty vehicle
Passenger car
Domestic
Imported
Light truck (<8,500 lbs GVWR)d
CAFE standards (mpg)c (model year)
Passenger car
Light trucke
KEY: CAFE = Corporate Average Fuel Economy; GVWR = gross vehicle weight rating; mpg = miles per gallon; U = data are unavailable.
a 1960-2006 data are for Passenger car and Other 2-axle, 4-tire vehicles, respectively. The data from 1960-2006 are not comparable to the data from 2007-14.
b From 1980 to 1994, Light duty vehicle, short wheel base (previously Passenger car) fuel efficiency includes motorcycles.

c Assumes 55% city and 45% highway-miles. The source calculated average miles per gallon for light-duty vehicles by taking the reciprocal of the sales-weighted average of gallons per mile. This is called the harmonic average.
d Beginning with FY 1999, the total Light truck fleet ceased to be categorized by either domestic or import fleets.
e No combined figure is available for 1980. In 1980, CAFE standard for 2 wheel drive, and 4 wheel drive light trucks were 16.0, and 14.0 mpg respectively.
NOTES

Data for 2007-14 were calculated using a new methodology developed by FHWA. Data for these years are based on new categories and are not comparable to previous years. The new category Light duty vehicle, short wheel base includes passenger cars, light trucks, vans and sport utility vehicles with a wheelbase (WB) equal to or less than 121 inches. The new category Light duty vehicle, long wheel base includes large passenger cars, vans, pickup trucks, and sport/utility vehicles with wheelbases (WB) larger than 121 inches.
The fuel efficiency figures for Light duty vehicles represent the sales-weighted harmonic average of the combined Passenger car and Light truck fuel economies.
